text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Tuesday.
VJESNIK

- U.N. Transitional Administrator for Eastern Slavonia Jacques Klein has changed municipal boundaries of seven Serb counties in the region ahead of local elections. Croatian government had no choice but to tacitly approve his decision.
- The government could pay off 150 million kuna debt owed by hospitals in Croatia's former war zones.
- Confectioner Kras has suspended production of candies due to shortage of glucose syrup. The government recently imposed a temporary ban on most sugar imports.
- Commentary: Croatia plans sale of its military industry products on Asian, African and Western markets in near future.
- There have been no scientific projects in Croatia to deal with cloning of either animals or humans, says deputy Science Minister Nikola Ruzinski.

- There are too many banks in Croatia and many of the small banks will have to merge to survive competition. They may also be bought by large and foreign banks, says Davor Holjevac of Zagrebacka Banka.
- Imports of gas will be increased from the current 750 million cubic metres a year to between 2.5 billion and 3 billion in the year 2010.
- Oil refinery in the port of Rijeka produces 7,000 tonnes of crude a day and Iran oil is now processed there for the first time in seven years.
- Croatia expects an increase of 30 percent in tourist trade this year, says head of Croatian Tourist Association Marijan Bulat.
VECERNJI LIST
- Croatian Health Insurance Fund ended 1996 with a 40.5 million kuna loss due to irregular payments for health insurance. Its total debt is put at 1.1 billion kuna.
- Croatia should soon sign an agreement with member countries of the Council of Europe on recognition of university degrees. Any Croatian student should then be able to compete for any job in Europe.
- Zagreb's Hotel Inter-Continental has been recently proclaimed the best in the chain of 58 such hotels in 40 countries.
SLOBODNA DALMACIJA
- Cars with Croatian flags crossed the rebuilt Maslenica highway bridge on the Adriatic coast. The original bridge was blown up by Serb rebels in 1991.

- Croatian diaspora and immigrants have so far invested at least seven billion kuna in Croatia of which 542 million have been invested through the Croatian Privatisation Fund. One billion kuna were directly invested in various enterprises.
- Croatian Privatisation Fund is close to selling 12.5 percent stake in Adriatic pipeline Janaf to Hungary's oil company MOL for a nominal price of almost 93 million German marks.
--- Zagreb newsroom, 385-1-4557075
